channel.title: Bloomberg Politics

item.title: Trump to End Federal Contracts With Harvard University
item.description: President Donald Trump’s administration is moving to cancel all remaining federal contracts with Harvard University, marking the latest escalation of its battle against the oldest and richest US school.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: The Baker Library of the Harvard Business School on the Harvard University campus in Boston, Massachusetts.

item.title: US Orders Pause in Student-Visa Interviews Ahead of New Vetting
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio ordered US embassies worldwide to stop scheduling new interviews for student-visa applicants as the Trump administration weighs stricter vetting of social-media profiles.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: Students on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Photographer: Simon Simard/Bloomberg

item.title: IMF Warns UK to Keep Budget in Check or Risk Market Revolt
item.description: UK Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves must stick to her fiscal rules and keep spending under control or risk a market backlash that undermines the government’s economic plans, the International Monetary Fund warned.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves delivers a speech during a reception for UK and EU businesses at Downing Street on May 19.

item.title: BBVA’s Sabadell Bid Delayed Further as Government Starts Review
item.description: Spain’s government decided to conduct its own review of BBVA SA’s bid for rival Banco Sabadell SA, after the country’s antitrust watchdog last month cleared the offer with some conditions.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Zuloaga

media:content.media:description: A BBVA bank branch in Valencia, Spain.

item.title: NY Wins Bid to Stop US From Freezing Funds in Congestion Fight
item.description: New York won a temporary freeze on potential Trump administration moves to withhold federal approvals or funds for the state’s transportation projects, as the president tries to end Manhattan’s congestion pricing program.
item.dc:creator: Chris Dolmetsch, Michelle Kaske

media:content.media:description: E-ZPass readers and license plate-scanning cameras over Park Avenue in New York, US, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. The Trump administration is threatening to stop future federal approvals for transportation projects in Manhattan and may withhold funding if New York City's congestion pricing program continues.

item.title: Texas Lawmakers Require the Ten Commandments in Every Classroom
item.description: Texas lawmakers voted to require public schools to display the Ten Commandments in every classroom, advancing a conservative priority before the end of the state legislature’s session next week.
item.dc:creator: Joe Lovinger

media:content.media:description: A classroom at the Woodson Independent School District school building in Woodson, TX on April 3, 2025.

item.title: Trump Warns Putin ‘Playing With Fire’ as Lawmakers Eye Sanctions
item.description: President Donald Trump warned in a social media post Tuesday that Russian leader Vladimir Putin was “playing with fire”, as the US weighs whether to target Moscow with additional sanctions over its long-range missile and drone barrage against Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: MOSCOW, RUSSIA - MAY 22: (RUSSIA OUT) Russian President Vladimir Putin speaks during an awards ceremony at the Saint Yekeaterina's Hall of the Kremlin, May 22, 2025 in Moscow, Russia. Putin gave awards to two dozen Russians during the ceremony, including participants and supporters of the military invasion of Ukraine. (Photo by Contributor/Getty Images)

item.title: US Fund Managers Put on Notice by $65 Billion Dutch Investor
item.description: Dutch pension fund PME is issuing a blanket warning to US money managers, amid concerns America’s investment industry is caving in to pressure from the Trump administration to abandon basic principles of stewardship.
item.dc:creator: Frances Schwartzkopff

media:content.media:description: President Trump signs executive orders during a ceremony in the Oval Office following the inauguration of his second term.

item.title: Milei Burnishes His Trump Ties by Hosting Health Chief RFK Jr.
item.description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. met President Javier Milei in Buenos Aires, signaling renewed Trump administration support for Argentina with the second trip by a US cabinet secretary in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Tobias

media:content.media:description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. met President Javier Milei in Buenos Aires on Tuesday. Source: Office of the Argentine Presidency

item.title: King Charles Delivers Carney's Economic Pledge to Canadian Parliament
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said he intends to lead Canada to “the largest transformation of its economy since the Second World War,” in a speech delivered by King Charles III to open the new parliamentary session.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: King Charles III and Queen Camilla take their seats to open the first session of the 45th Parliament of Canada as Mark Carney, left, and Marc Gold, right, look on in the Senate of Canada in Ottawa, on May 27.

item.title: Southeast Asia Leaders Make a Veiled Jab at US Tariff Actions
item.description: Southeast Asian leaders called out unilateral trade actions in a joint statement late Tuesday, without specifically mentioning the US — the region’s largest export customer.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey, Philip Heijmans

media:content.media:description: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's prime minister, left, and Zafrul Tengku Abdul Aziz, Malaysia's international trade and industry minister, during a news conference at the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. Chinese Premier Li Qiang rallied a group of Southeast Asian and Gulf states to deepen cooperation, as the Asian nation ramps up its charm offensive abroad to counter US efforts to isolate the economy.

item.title: West African Coast Could Boost Revenue for Jihadists, US Warns
item.description: Islamist militants in West Africa could develop new revenue streams if they succeed in reaching the coast, the head of the US military’s Africa Command warned Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Peter Martin

media:content.media:description: A woman walks between shelters and tents at the Wendou 2 IDP displacement camp in Dori, in Burkina Faso, on May 29, 2024.

item.title: Trump Threatens California Funding Freeze Over Trans Athletes
item.description: President Donald Trump threatened to withhold federal funding from California, accusing Governor Gavin Newsom of failing to comply with an executive order barring transgender people from competing in women’s sports.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: The California State Capitol building in Sacramento, California, U.S., on Wednesday, July 7, 2021. California has reinstated a mask mandate for all lawmakers and employees at the state capitol regardless of vaccination status following an outbreak of nine Covid-19 cases there, reported the San Francisco Chronicle.

item.title: US and EU Race for Trade Deal With Six Weeks Left Until Truce Expires
item.description: The European Union and the US signaled a willingness to end a stalemate and work toward a trade deal over the next six weeks, in the first major thaw in their frigid economic relations since President Donald Trump’s second term began in January.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump said he would extend the deadline for the European Union to face 50% tariffs until July 9 after a phone call with Commission President Ursula von der Leyen. Bloomberg News Editor News Editor Tony Czuczka shares what we know so far.

item.title: India Sees US Trade Deal as Key to Lowering External Risks
item.description: A successful trade deal with the US could help India mitigate external risks and boost its exports, the South Asian country said, as its government seeks to speed up talks and reach an interim agreement.
item.dc:creator: Satviki Sanjay

media:content.media:description: Mundra Port in Gujarat, India.

item.title: Supreme Court Rejects Student Appeal on ‘Two Genders’ Shirt
item.description: The US Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal from a public middle school student who said his free speech rights were violated when his principal barred him from wearing a T-shirt saying “there are only two genders.”
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC.

item.title: Farage Backs Benefit Hikes in Challenge From Starmer’s Left
item.description: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage vowed to scrap a limit on child benefits, vying for traditional Labour voters and putting pressure on Prime Minister Keir Starmer to reverse his own stance on the controversial policy.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White

media:content.media:description: Reform UK leader Nigel Farage on May 27. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: South Africa Lawmakers Slam Starlink Plan Over ‘Back Door’ Entry
item.description: South Africa’s lawmakers challenged a plan to provide an alternative to Black ownership rules that will pave the way for Elon Musk’s Starlink to operate in Africa’s biggest economy.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele, Loni Prinsloo

item.title: Trump Lauds EU for Speeding Tariff Negotiations After Threat
item.description: President Donald Trump said he was encouraged the European Union is speeding up negotiations on trade, days after he said the bloc would face 50% tariffs if they fail to reach a deal with the US.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: Container ships at Hamburg Port in Hamburg, Germany.

item.title: China Calls on Asean, Gulf States to Create ‘Big Market’
item.description: Chinese Premier Li Qiang rallied a group of Southeast Asian and Gulf states to deepen cooperation and touted his country’s economic strength, as Beijing ramps up its charm offensive abroad to counter US efforts to isolate the economy.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao, Kok Leong Chan

media:content.media:description: Li Qiang with leaders at the Asean-GCC-China Summitin Kuala Lumpur on May 27.

item.title: Ramaphosa Recalls His Bemusement at Trump Oval Office Encounter
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa laughed off Donald Trump’s Oval Office ambush, in his first direct comments since returning from the encounter with his American counterpart last week.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele, Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and Cyril Ramaphosa, South Africa’s president, during a meeting in the Oval Office on May 21.

item.title: Germany Weighs Curbs on Israel Arms Exports on Gaza Concerns
item.description: Germany is considering restrictions on military exports to Israel over concerns about civilian suffering in Gaza, a notable shift from one of the country’s biggest weapons suppliers.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs, Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Smoke following an Israeli strike in Jabalia, Gaza Strip on May 25.

item.title: Polish Nationalist Brushes Off Reports About Checkered Past
item.description: Poland’s nationalist presidential candidate Karol Nawrocki is fighting off fresh allegations about his past that threaten to damage the boxer-turned-politician days before a tight election.
item.dc:creator: Wojciech Moskwa

media:content.media:description: Karol Nawrocki in Warsaw, on May 25. Photographer: Omar Marques/Getty Images Europe

item.title: Russia Backs Turkey for New Ukraine Talks After Nixing Vatican
item.description: Russia supports Turkey hosting another round of peace talks with Ukraine after a first meeting made no progress in US efforts to halt more than three years of war.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer, Taylan Bilgic

media:content.media:description: Sergei Lavrov, right, and Hakan Fidan in Moscow on May 27.

item.title: India Allows Private Firms to Build Advanced Fighter Jets
item.description: India will for the first time allow private firms to design and develop advanced warplanes, as it beefs up domestic defense production to reduce reliance on imports.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Indian Air Force fighter jets perform during the inaugural day of a military aviation exhibition at the Yelahanka Air Force Station in Bengaluru.

item.title: India and Pakistan’s Water Wars Are Just Beginning
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Dan Strumpf

media:content.media:description: A view of a dry path of Indus River in Jamshoro and Kotri district in Hyderabad, Pakistan, on May 6, 2025. Pakistan has warned of a full force response to any attempt by India to divert or block its share of water under the Indus water treaty. (Photo by Jan Ali Laghari / Middle East Images / Middle East Images via AFP) (Photo by JAN ALI LAGHARI/Middle East Images/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: JAN ALI LAGHARI/AFP

item.title: Romania’s Georgescu Exits Politics After Ban, Denting Far Right
item.description: Romania’s one-time presidential frontrunner, nationalist Calin Georgescu, said he plans to withdraw from politics, potentially weakening the Black Sea nation’s far-right movement.
item.dc:creator: Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Calin Georgescu arrives at the Prosecutor General's Office in Bucharest, on May 27.

item.title: Merz Says Kyiv’s Allies Ended Curbs on Russia Strikes Months Ago
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz said Ukraine’s allies decided several months ago to drop restrictions on the use of the weapons they’ve provided to allow Kyiv to strike targets deep inside Russia.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs, Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Friedrich Merz speaks during a joint press conference with the Finnish Prime Minister in Turku, Finland, on May 27.

item.title: Slovak Premier Rejects Germany’s Warning on Cutting EU Funding
item.description: Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico dismissed a German threat to withhold European Union funding over alleged rule-of-law lapses as unacceptable and contrary to the bloc’s democratic principles.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

media:content.media:description: Slovakia’s Prime Minister Robert Fico. Photographer: Armend Nimani/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Thailand Clears Plan to Exit US Intellectual Property Watchlist
item.description: Thailand’s cabinet approved a new framework for enforcement of intellectual property rights as the Southeast Asian nation seeks to exit from a US watchlist ahead of tariff talks with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Pathom Sangwongwanich

media:content.media:description: Pichai Naripthaphan Photographer: Stefan Wermuth/Bloomberg
